finalProject

Interface ApplicationConstants

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    BoundingBox, GraphicObject, KeyframedStickFigure, MainClass, PlayerFace, StickFigure

    public interface ApplicationConstants
    I use this interface to store all application-wide constants relative to dimensions of the window and world. Classes that require access to this information just need to "implement ApplicationConstants". All calculations are made for a world reference frame with axes parallel to that of the window: - x axis horizontal and pointing to the right of the window - y axis vertical and pointing up in the window. This is the version we did in class, somewhat cleaned up, with javadoc comments for documentation, and some regular comments to attract your attention to features and weaknesses. In this version of the interface, we set the dimensions (width and height) of the window (in pixels) and the bounds of the world (XMIN, XMAX, YMIN, YMAX in world units). All the scales, conversion factors, and location of the world's origin relative to the window (in pixels) are calculated from these 6 values.
    Author:
    Jean-Yves Herv√© and PaigeCourtemanche

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static boolean BAIL_OUT_IF_ASPECT_RATIOS_DONT_MATCH
      Set this constant to true if you want to ensure that you don't end up with different aspect ratios for world and window (which could could result in either clipping at top and bottom of the window (if WORLD_HEIGHT < PIXEL_TO_WORLD*WINDOW_WIDTH) or non-painted bands at the top and bottom of the window (if WORLD_HEIGHT < PIXEL_TO_WORLD*WINDOW_WIDTH)
      static int DO_NOTHING
      The possible states for a stick figure or player face to be in

    • Field Detail

      • BAIL_OUT_IF_ASPECT_RATIOS_DONT_MATCH

        static final boolean BAIL_OUT_IF_ASPECT_RATIOS_DONT_MATCH
        Set this constant to true if you want to ensure that you don't end up with different aspect ratios for world and window (which could could result in either clipping at top and bottom of the window (if WORLD_HEIGHT < PIXEL_TO_WORLD*WINDOW_WIDTH) or non-painted bands at the top and bottom of the window (if WORLD_HEIGHT < PIXEL_TO_WORLD*WINDOW_WIDTH)
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • WINDOW_WIDTH

        static final int WINDOW_WIDTH
        Window width (in pixels)
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • WINDOW_HEIGHT

        static final int WINDOW_HEIGHT
        Window height (in pixels)
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • XMIN

        static final float XMIN
        Lower bound for x coordinate (in world units), seen at left edge of the window. It is simply the horizontal pixel travel from the world's origin to the left edge of the window, converted to world units. This value could be positive if the world's origin is outside the window, to its left
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • XMAX

        static final float XMAX
        Upper bound for x coordinate (in world units), seen at right edge of the window. It is simply the horizontal pixel travel from the world's origin to the right edge of the window, converted to world units. This value could be positive if the world's origin is outside the window, to its left
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • YMIN

        static final float YMIN
        Lower bound for y coordinate (in world units), seen at bottom edge of the window. It is simply the vertical pixel travel from the world's origin to the bottom edge of the window, converted to world units, and sign inverted so that y points"up". This value could be positive if the world's origin is outside the window, above it
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • YMAX

        static final float YMAX
        Upper bound for y coordinate (in world units), seen at top edge of the window. It is simply the vertical pixel travel from the world's origin to the top edge of the window, converted to world units, and sign inverted so that y points"up. This value could be negative if the world's origin is outside the window, below it
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • WORLD_WIDTH

        static final float WORLD_WIDTH
        Width of my world (in world units, here: cm)
        See Also:

        Constant Field Values

      • DRAW_IN_PIXELS_SCALE

        static final float DRAW_IN_PIXELS_SCALE
        Scale that needs to be applied in order to draw stuff in pixels (e.g. a strokeWeight) while rendering an object set in world units.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • WORLD_X

        static final float WORLD_X
        Windows horizontal coordinate (in pixels) of the world's origin: displacement in pixels from the left edge of the window. Positive iff XMIN < 0
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • WORLD_Y

        static final float WORLD_Y
        Windows vertical coordinate (in pixels) of the world's origin: displacement in pixels from the top edge of the window. Positive iff YMAX > 0
        See Also:
